newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: South African "Grey Diplomat" awaits Zairean talks.
newsitem.headline: South African "Grey Diplomat" awaits Zairean talks.

text.p: The SAS Outeniqua, bought at a fire-sale price from Russia in 1993, is the depleted South African Navy's newest, biggest and ugliest ship -- dubbed "the Grey Diplomat" for its humanitarian missions.

Now it is reported to be waiting off the West African coast to serve as a platform for the first face-to-face peace talks between President Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire and his rebel rival, Laurent Kabila.
Captain Fred Marais said the 166-metre (545-foot) ship has two luxury suites on either side of the accommodation block awkwardly perched near the bow of the 21,025-tonne ice-breaker.
And the galley will be able to serve the Zairean rivals and their host, President Nelson Mandela, food as good as they will get anywhere.
"For a naval vessel, she's really quite comfortable," he said.
The mid-section of the slate-grey vessel is an almost clear space for cargo work of container transport, and a pad on the stern could handle most medium-sized helicopters, he added.
The Outeniqua, named for a mountain range inshore from the Indian Ocean port of Mossel Bay, was built by Russia as a commercial ice-breaker with military specifications.
Initially called the Juvent, the two-year-old ship was bought for $12.8 million, which South African defence analysts estimated was around a third of its replacement cost.

The ship carries two Puma helicopters and is capable of a modest 17.5 knots. As a support vessel for South Africa's permanent Antarctic expedition, it is ideal with an ice-breaking capability designed to help clear Russia's northern sea lanes.
The Outeniqua and the supply ship Drakensberg are the South African Navy's only full-sized vessels. The rest are locally built patrol boats and a small fleet of Israeli gunboats.

In 1993 the Outeniqua -- which boasts a well-equipped hospital -- delivered to Trieste in Italy a 130-bed portable field hospital donated by the country's Moslem community to fellow Moslems in Bosnia.
The ship spent its commissioning cruise delivering medical supplies to Indian Ocean islands and has made regular voyages to the country's Antarctic base.
In 1995, the Outeniqua transported 2,000 former political prisoners to a reunion with Mandela on Robben Island in Cape Town's Table Bay.
